subject: RE: [junit] assertContains? -> junit development question?
msgSnippet: A few more methods in the assert class will not affect the extensibility of JUnit. Nor will it make JUnit any more difficult to understand. But it will enable
messageBody:
A few more methods in the assert class will not affect the extensibility of JUnit. Nor will it make JUnit any more difficult to understand. But it will enable new JUnit users to have more utilities at their fingertips. I think that most users are confused initially when they come to JUnit because it doesn't do a whole lot. Personally, I don't care a whole lot for my own use, but I think that adding some more utilities to JUnit will enhance it's out-of-the-box usability. The power users will eventually get under the hood and make extensions where it suits them.

What's confusing to me about the assert class is that it only goes part of the way. It provides a bunch of assertions but then an arbitrary line in the sand has been drawn to say that these are all that anyone should need. This is confusing. I would rather see the Assert class simplified down to only one method: assertTrue. This would then beg for the extensibility you describe and the framework would at least be consistent. Otherwise, we should recognise the Assert class as a utility for programmers and load it up. You don't have to the methods there if you don't want to.

Chris

-----Original Message-----
From: Shane Celis
Sent: Friday, April 05, 2002 2:03 PM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [junit] assertContains? -> junit development question?


I have to disagree. I like the fact that the JUnit framework is itself
small, easy to comprehend, therefore making it easy to extend. One
thing that perturbs me about the Assert class is the fact that it's
static. If I want to override assertTrue() globally, for instance to
provide more verbose output, or to change it's behavior so that a
failure won't result in an exception being thrown thereby discontinuing
the rest of the test, I have to edit the JUnit Assert class itself. If
Assert were an instance class I could avoid this, and easily add the
assert extensions that everyone is asking for.

I do believe that they should be extensions to JUnit, without bloating
the original Assert class.

-shane

p.s. Yes, I could make my own base TestCase class, but this doesn't
work retroactively, and certainly isn't a solution I would want to
foster for Assert Extension classes.

On Friday, April 5, 2002, at 11:42 AM, Chris Eppstein wrote:

> So your argument is that we really don't need anything other than
> assertTrue? I'd have to disagree.
>
> JUnit is a TESTING FRAMEWORK. By using it, testing should be made
> easier. I'd like to not have to reinvent the wheel for many of these
> assertions. I understand that I can easily write my own assertion
> library in just a couple hours but why should I have to? Certainly,
> after years of use, we have identified many assertions that would be
> useful to the community at large. As they are identified, it seems
> natural for JUnit to provide them in future releases.
>
> -Chris
>

>> do containment checks by writing
>>
>> if(str.indexOf(keywordStr) < 0) {
>> fail("failed.");
>> }
>
> Is there something wrong with:
>
> assertTrue( str.indexOf(keywordStr) >= 0 )?
>
> I used to want many, many custom assertions. I now believe it's cleaner
> simply
> to build a lot of custom methods answering boolean, then using
> assertTrue() and
> assertFalse(). What changes in your example is the condition, and not
> the
> assertion mechanism.
>
> You create your own abstract TestCase class with your custom
> boolean-logic
> methods.
>
> public abstract class MyTestCase extends TestCase {
> public static boolean containsText(final String string, final String
> pattern) {
> return string.indexOf(pattern) >= 0;
> }
> ...
> }
>
> ...
>
> public class SomeTest extends MyTestCase {
> public void testSomething() {
> assertTrue(containsText("Hello", "el"));
> }
> }
>
> ...
>
> Of course, after enough of this, your code starts to look like
> procedural
> programming code, because what you REALLY want is to extend String,
> which you
> can't do. If you really want to, you can wrap String and provide the
> extra
> methods.
>
> public class MyString {
> private final String string;
>
> public MyString(final String aString) {
> string = aString;
> }
>
> public boolean contains(final String pattern) {
> return string.indexOf(pattern) >= 0;
> }
>
> public boolean matchesRegex(final String regex) {
> // ORO magic...
> }
> }
>
> It's cleaner in one respect and uglier in another.
